title-group.article-title: Refined delamination characterization for composite laminates using digital means

article-meta.aff: 1Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Anna University of Technology Tirunelveli, India
2Department of Manufacturing Engineering, Annamalai University, Chidambaram, India
4Department of Mechanical Engineering, Government College of Engineering, Tirunelveli, India
5National Institute for Interdisciplinary Science and Technology, CSIR, Trivandrum, India

author-notes.corresp: J Selwin Rajadurai, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Government College of Engineering, Tirunelveli, India Email: j_selwinrajadurai@yahoo.co.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Drilling is most widely applied to composite materials; nevertheless, the damage induced by this operation on composite materials may reduce drastically the component performance. In order to establish the damage level, delamination is measured quantitatively using digital means. A comparison between the conventional (FD) and adjusted (FDA) delamination factor is presented. In order to quantify the delamination effectively, ‘a refined delamination factor (FDR)’ is proposed. The accuracy of the proposed criteria is validated using experimental results.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to high specific strength and specific stiffness, excellent corrosive resisting property, low thermal expansion and high damping characteristics usage of fiber reinforced plastic (FRP) composites finds its application in various fields like automobile and aerospace industries. Composite materials are constituted of two phases, namely, fiber and matrix. Fibers are the principal load-carrying members in composite system of materials, whereas the matrix materials often act as load-transferring mediums. Glass, carbon, and aramid fibers are the commonly used fibrous mediums in industrial applications. Among them, glass fibers are more economical touse. Hence, the glass fibers are most frequently used in structural constructions because of their specific strength properties. Epoxy resins are widely used as matrix in many fiber-reinforced composites since it offers good chemical and mechanical behaviors under loading conditions. In spite of the fact that the composites are usually produced to near-net shape, an additional machining operation such as drilling is often required. The cutting tool action during machining may damage the work material surface. In addition to aesthetic issues, the risk of mechanical failures too increases substantially.

sec.title: Conventional delamination factor (FD) and adjusted delamination factor (FDA)
sec.p: The main difficulty associated with drilling of a composite material is delamination failure. When the stresses induced in the layers of the laminate during the drilling operation exceed the interlaminar strength of the laminate, delamination failure occurs. Two delamination mechanisms associated with drilling FRP are known as peel-up at the drill entrance and push-out at the drill exit. The key for solving the problem lies inthe reduction of the thrust force while drilling. Opticalmicroscopy and scanning and digital images are employed to measure the delamination qualitatively. The same can be measured quantitatively by Equation (1). The delamination factor (FD) may be calculated from the ratio of the maximum diameter (Dmax) of the delamination zone to the drill diameter (D0), as follows1 (1)

Alternatively, the ratio of the delaminated area to thehole area may also be used. In this case, the adjusteddelamination factor (FDA) is calculated from Equation (2), in which, the first term of Equation (2) represents the size of the crack contribution (conventional delamination factor – FD) and the second term the damage area contribution2 (2) where AD is the damage area, Amax the area related to themaximum diameter of the delamination zone (Dmax),and A0 the area of the nominal hole which corresponds to D0.

The influence of factors, such as tool geometry andmachining parameters, on delamination has been studied by several researchers. Davim and Reis3 compared the influence of different drill geometries on the delamination of hand lay-up glass fiber reinforced plastic (GFRP) laminates. A toolmaker’s microscope was used to evaluate the damage as the machining parameters were altered. The delamination factor was considered as the ratio of maximum diameter in the damage zone to the drill diameter. The results indicated that the damage increases with cutting speed and feedrate. Arul et al.4 induced axial vibrations in the feed direction and studied the influence of the vibrationfrequency and amplitude when drilling GFRP composites. In order to establish the extent of the defects caused by drilling, specimens were examined using an optical microscope coupled to an image analyzer. The delamination factor was obtained from the ratio of the maximum diameters in the damage zone to the drill diameter. Aoyama et al.5 investigated the damage after drilling holes of small diameter in printed wiring boards and concluded that the delamination (which leads to ion migration) is generated along the fiber in the hole wall surface as the surface roughness increases. According to these authors, the thickness of the fiber bundle affects the internal damage of the hole and this damage increases together with the thickness of the fiber bundle for the same edge position angle. Only a few works have been conducted using high-speed maching (HSM) and obtaining a relationship between the various controllable parameters and their influence on the quality of hole.Owing to the fact that HSM leads to lower cutting forces and energy consumption together with higher removal rates, less damage in the work piece is expected. Inoue et al.6 investigated the relationship between the internal damage around the drilled hole and the number of holes produced. Glass fiber reinforced epoxy resin used in printed circuit board was tested as the work material. The holes were drilled under the following conditions: spindle speeds from 20,000 to 80,000 rpm and feed rates from 10 to 50 µm/rev using 1 mm diameter drills. The results showed that when drilling at high feed rates, a large number of holes are produced with uniform quality, whereas at low feed rates, a small number of holes with high quality are produced. Finally, the authors concluded that the ratio of the radius of the drill to the width of the yarn is an important factor to estimate the tool life of small-diameter drills. In the case of drills with a radius larger than the width of the yarn, high wear rates were observed. In order to reduce tool wear when drilling composite materials, Kao7 investigated the tribological properties of coated drills against glass fiber reinforced epoxy resin. The results indicated that the tool life was increased twice on coating them with 5% MoS2–Cr when compared to uncoated drills. In addition to that the quality of the holes was not impaired by high-speed drilling through holes at 100,000 rpm. Campos Rubio et al.8 discussed about performance of HSM drilling of glass/epoxy composite materials with minimal damage. Marques et al.9 depicted delamination analysis of carbon fiber reinforced laminate using conventional delamination factor and cutting force measurement under various drilling conditions. Advanced radiography was employed to evaluate the damage. Durao et al.10 drilled quasi-isotropic carbon/epoxy laminates with four different drill geometries, one of them with the additional use of a pilot hole. In their research, in addition to measurement of delamination by delamination factor (FD), surface roughness of drilled surface was also characterized. de Albuquerque et al.11 discussed about the delamination caused in laminate plates by drilling and evaluated using radiographic images. Toaccomplish this evaluation, they employed artificial neural network in the analysis of the radiographic images. Durao et al.12 concluded that low feed rates were appropriate for laminate drilling, as it reduced the axial thrust force, and hence, delamination failure can be reduced.

Even though the delamination is estimated quantitatively by various researchers using either delamination factor or adjusted delamination factor, in this study, it was observed that the specimen with lower adjusted delamination factor gets failed more quickly than the specimens with a higher one. This insists the need for a revision in the current form of adjusted delamination factor. Hence, in the revised form of delamination factor equation, in addition to damage zone size, drill diameter and area corresponding to nominal diameter, importance was given to severity of damages.

sec.title: Experimental procedure
sec.p:
Drilling experiments were conducted on a CNC machining center with 5 kW power. The spindle speed range is200–2500 rpm with a resolution of 1 rpm. The feed range is in between 5 and 200 mm/min. The laminates were produced by the hand lay-up technique and were made up of epoxy matrix reinforced with 62% weight of woven glass fiber with laminate signature of [0 ± 45]5 [0/90]2. Fourteen layers of glass fiber were used, resulting in a laminate that is 9.57 mm thick. Table 1 presents the properties of the composite material used. Table 1.
Mechanical properties of composite material used
Fiber type E-glass 21xK43 Gevetex
Matrix type LY556/DY063 epoxy
Fiber volume fraction Vf 0.62
Longitudinal modulus, E11 (GPa) 34.41
Transverse modulus, E22 (GPa) 6.53
In-plane shear modulus, G12 (GPa) 3.43
Major Poisson’s ratio, ν12 0.217
Longitudinal tensile strength, XT (MPa) 674
Longitudinal compressive strength, XC (MPa) 420
Transverse tensile strength, YT (MPa) 520
Transverse compressive strength, YC (MPa) 406
Longitudinal shear strength, SL (MPa) 282
Transverse shear strength, ST (MPa) 306

The composite laminate was fixed on the machining center using appropriate clamping device. Then, the laminate was drilled using three different drill bits, namely, router, end mill cutter, and twist drill, the details of which are shown in Figure 1. Holes were drilled in three different sizes (8, 10, and 12 mm), each by the drill bits. Drilling was performed by varying spindle speeds and feeds and Table 2 presents the range of feed rates (millimeter per minute) used in the experimental work. The same set of feed rates was used for spindle speeds of 1000, 1200, and 1400 rpm. The drilling process carried out in the machining center is shown in Figure 2. Table 2.
Range of feed rates for a spindle speed of 1000 rpm
Test no. 1 2 3 4 5 6
Feed rate (mm/min) 25 50 75 100 125 150
Figure 1.
Various types of drilling cutters of 10 mm: (a) router; (b) end mill cutter; and (c) twist drill. Figure 2.
Drilling process in the machining center.

Eighteen holes were drilled for the specified cutting parameters for a single cutting tool of an individual size. Total number of holes required for various drill bits anddifferent sizes required for this study was worked out to be 162. In order to account for unforced errors and damages induced during machining operation, three holes of same parameter were drilled.

sec.title: Result and discussion
sec.p:
The damage was captured qualitatively using a Nikon 300 digital camera with ST 800 flash, with resolution of300 dpi and 8 bits (Figure 3). The size of the damage zone was measured quantitatively using a neural network built in MATLAB.13 The image captured using the digital camera is taken for training. During training, the background is eliminated by ground truth technique and certain features like primarycolor components of the image under study are extracted and selected. At the time of testing, same features are tested with the trained neural network andthe mean square error is calculated and the trainingis done till the iteration process reaches the maximum, and finally, the results obtained were classified bydamaged areas as: heavily, medium, and lightly damaged. Three zones were colored as follows (a) heavily damaged area(red); (b) medium damaged area (green); and (c) lightly damaged area (light red). The flow chart of the proposed algorithm is represented in Figure 4. Figure 3.
Digital image of holes drilled by end mill cutter (10 mm). Figure 4.
Flow chart of the proposed algorithm using neural network.

Using Equations (1) and (2), delamination factor (FD)and adjusted delamination factor (FDA) proposed by various researchers were calculated and presented in Table 3; the graphs are shown in Figures 5 and 6. From Figure 5, it can be observed that delamination factor (FD) reaches a maximum value when the holes are drilled with a spindle speed of 1200 rpm and feed rate 50 mm/min and minimum at a cutting speed of 1400 rpm and feed rate 50 mm/min for the holes drilled with 10 mm end mill cutter. Figure 6 shows the plot for FDA for different cutting conditions. In this case, from the graph, it can be observed that the adjusted delamination factor reaches the maximum value at 1000 rpm with a feed rate of 75 mm/min and minimum at 1000 rpm with a feed rate of 125 mm/min for the holes of same size when drilled with end mill cutter. Table 3.

Figure 5.
Effect of feed and spindle speed on conventional delamination factor (FD) for 10 mm end mill. Figure 6.
Effect of feed and spindle speed on adjusted delamination factor (FDA) for 10 mm end mill.
On the other hand, the drilled specimens were tested by the following tests to confirm and validate the value of FD and FDA.

American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) has proposed two test standards: They are three-point bend test (hereafter 3PT) and modified short beam shear (MSBS) test. The is 3PT based on standard D2344 to measure interlaminar shear stress of laminated composites subjected to transverse loads. The schematic arrangement of this test is shown in Figure 7 and the corresponding pictorial representation of the test in a computerized universal testing machine in Figure 8. Figure 7.
Configuration of 3PT. Figure 8.
Test arrangement of 3PT.

The MSBS, based on ASTM D790, is also used to estimate the interlaminar shear stress. The schematic and test arrangement for this test are shown in Figures 9 and 10, respectively. Both these tests offer failure load of the specimen in kilonewtons. Using this failure load, the interlaminar shear stress can be computed from the following equation.14 (3) where τxzmax refers to the maximum induced shear stress in the xz plane, in which x denotes the axial direction of the beam and z the thickness direction with the origin coinciding with the mid-thickness plane; pmax the maximum failure load; b the width of the specimen; and D the thickness of the specimen. Figure 9.
Configuration of MSBS test. Figure 10.
Test arrangement of MSBS test.

The results of both these tests and the computed interlaminar shear stress are given in Table 4. Table 4.
Failure load and interlaminar shear stress by 3PT and MSBS tests for holes drilled with 10 mm end mill for different conditions
Test Parameters Trials Failure load (kN) Interlaminar shear stress (MPa)
3PT 1000 rpm, 25mm/min feed (case 1) 1 298.42 352.54
2 299.67 354.89
3 296.56 351.99
Average 298.21 353.14
1000 rpm, 150 mm/min feed (case 2) 1 373.07 452.61
2 371.65 453.78
3 372.48 450.12
Average 372.40 452.17
MSBS 1000 rpm, 25 mm/min feed 1 242.49 294.19
2 243.57 295.95
3 241.11 292.67
Average 242.39 294.27
1000 rpm, 150 mm/min feed 1 309.41 375.38

Average 308.56 374.66

From the above validation tests, the following observation has been made.
Average failure load estimated using 3PT for holes drilled at 1000 rpm and feed rate 25 mm/min is 298.21 kN
Corresponding interlaminar shear stress is 353.14 MPa.
Average failure load estimated using MSBS test is 242.39 kN and corresponding interlaminar shear stress 294.27 MPa.
Average failure load estimated using 3PT for holes drilled at 1000 rpm and 150 mm/min feed rate is 372.40 kN.
Corresponding interlaminar shear stress is 452.17 MPa.
Average failure load estimated using MSBS test is 308.56 kN and corresponding interlaminar shear stress 374.66 MPa.
Holes drilled with a feed rate of 25 mm/min is more prone to failure than that with 150 mm/min.

The test values obtained by 3PT and MSBS tests do not correlate with the values of FD and FDA obtained using a neural network built in MATLAB.13 Hence, it is necessary to fine tune the image process by the following method. It is a seven-stage process and importance is given to the depth of damage, which is called severity of damage. Among the seven stages shown in Figure 11, from the first three stages, severity of damages and area of damage are estimated. From the gray-scale images, represented in the subsequent four stages, maximum length of damage (Dmax) was calculated using the neural network built in MATLAB. Figure 11.
Stages for the calculation of area of damage and Dmax.

Existing delamination factor or adjusted delamination factor depends either on maximum length of damage (Dmax) or maximum damage area (Amax) and area of damage zone (AD), respectively. Various researchers calculated the value of maximum damage area (Amax) only by considering the maximum diameter of the delamination zone (Dmax). It can be observed from Table 5 that the total area of damage (AD) for a hole drilled with a feed rate of 25 mm/min and at 1000 rpm (case 1) is 62.22 mm2, whereas for a feed rate of 150 mm/min and for the same speed (case 2), it is 69.36 mm2 only. Magnitude of FDA for the hole mentioned in first case is 1.804 while for the later only 1.907. Based on the concept proposed in literature, it can be decided that the hole considered in second case is more prone to damage when compared with the first. When these holes are processed using the concept of neural network, it was observed that the damages are distributed in case 2 when compared with case 1. Table 5.
Refined delamination factor for holes drilled with 10 mm end mill for different conditions
Speed Feed Maximum length of damage, Dmax Total damage area, AD Heavily damaged area, AH Medium damaged area, AM Lightly damaged area, AL FDR
(rpm) (mm/min) (mm) (mm2) (mm2) (mm2) (mm2) (mm2)
1000 25 13.50 62.22 13.03 23.02 26.17 1.709
50 15.43 80.50 9.37 36.96 34.17 1.917
75 15.08 93.69 7.06 34.68 51.95 1.818
100 13.81 42.47 6.30 10.75 25.42 1.539
125 12.62 25.82 2.44 8.02 15.36 1.325
150 13.92 69.36 4.92 35.34 29.10 1.650
1200 25 13.58 44.40 3.70 12.98 27.72 1.463
50 16.66 53.95 13.02 22.20 18.73 2.019
75 13.75 51.59 6.73 22.20 22.66 1.586
100 14.22 34.62 4.04 12.66 17.92 1.533
125 12.62 40.67 2.31 12.06 26.30 1.333
150 13.87 101.96 6.91 57.29 37.76 1.929
1400 25 14.16 62.34 7.81 20.99 33.54 1.647
50 12.61 59.63 3.91 23.04 32.68 1.414
75 14.12 37.81 4.14 12.29 21.38 1.524
100 13.00 52.34 2.81 16.72 32.81 1.399
125 14.07 49.18 4.66 12.01 32.51 1.532
150 13.59 91.05 5.50 36.36 49.19 1.646

Hence, the measurement of total area of damage (AD), which is mainly concentrated around the vicinity of drilled hole, alone is not sufficient to quantify the delamination factor. This is justified by both the validation tests and it is observed that the holes drilled with 1000 rpm and feed rate 25 mm/min have the values of failure load of 298.21 kN and interlaminar shear stress 353.40 MPa by 3PT test and 242.39 kN and 294.27 MPa by MSBS test, respectively, which is more prone to failure than the holes drilled with 1000 rpm and feed rate 150 mm/min, which have the values of failure load of 372.40 kN and interlaminar shear stress 452.17 MPa by3PT test and 308.56 kN and 374.66 MPa by MSBS test, respectively. Hence, it is very essential to refine the formula mentioned in Equation (2) for the calculation of adjusted delamination factor to correlate with the test values.

This process of refining should include the effect of severity of damage. In order to refine the adjusted delamination factor (FDA), in addition to the variables Dmax and D0, the heavily affected region should also be accounted for. In the case of refined delamination factor, the total damage area is further divided into three areas, namely, heavily damaged area (AH), medium damaged area (AM), and lightly damaged area (AL), depending upon severity of damage.

From Table 5, it can be observed that the heavily damaged area (AH) for hole drilled with feed rate 25 mm/min and 1000 rpm is 13.03 mm2, whereas it is only 4.92 mm2 for the hole drilled with feed rate 150 mm/min for the same speed. Hence, in the formulation of refined delamination factor, importance shouldbe given for the severity of damage in addition to the maximum length of damage, total damage area,and size of the hole. Keeping these points in mind, it is proposed that the delamination failure can be effectively characterized using Buckingham’s π theorem.15,16

The Buckingham’s π theorem states ‘If there are n variables in a physical phenomenon and if these variables contain m fundamental dimensions, then the variables are arranged into (n − m) dimensionless terms.’ Each term is called π term. Accordingly, as discussed earlier, in the expression for delamination factor, dueimportance should be given to severity of damage in addition to Dmax and D0. Here, the terms DmaxD0 (AHA0), (AMA0), and (ALA0) were identified as dimensionless π terms.The procedure for the development of the proposedrefined delamination factor FDR can be summarized as follows: FDR = f(Dmax, D0, A0, AH, AM, AL). This equation can also be expressed in terms of π terms as f(π1, π2, π3) = 0.
The π terms are expressed as

Similarly
and
Solving the above, the refined delamination factor FDR can be expressed asFDR = (4)

Calculated values of FDR for the holes drilled by 10 mm end mill with required variables for the calculation are tabulated in Table 5. Figure 12 shows the variation of FDR with feed rates for different spindle speeds. Figure 12.
Effect of feed and spindle speed on refined delamination factor (FDR) for 10 mm end mill.

To validate the refined delamination factor, 27 laminate specimens were drilled using three different tools, namely, router, end mill cutter, and twist drill with the three different sizes of 8, 10, and 12 mm, each by the tools at spindle speeds 1000, 1200, and 1400 rpm for the feed rates 25, 50, 75, 100, 125, and 150 mm/min, with three trials. That is, 486 holes were formed, out of which one set is shown in Figure 13. The capability of the refined delamination factor to predict the interlaminar failure is validated for these holes with reference to the experimental values. Figures 14–16 show the plots of various delamination factors with failure load estimated from 3PT for holes drilled at 1000, 1200, and 1400 rpm, respectively. Figure 13.
Digital image of drilled holes. Figure 14.
Plot of various delamination factors with failure load from 3PT for 10 mm end mill at a spindle speed of 1000 rpm. Figure 15.
Plot of various delamination factors with failure load from 3PT for 10 mm end mill at a spindle speed of 1200 rpm. Figure 16.
Plot of various delamination factors with failure load from 3PT for 10 mm end mill at a spindle speed of 1400 rpm.

The summarized results are given below:
Refined delamination factor (FDR) characterizes thedelamination in an effective manner since theformulation of FDR considers the severity of damage.
The above fact was validated from the experimental results. In order to validate this, 3PT and MSBS were carried out.
Optical means associated with neural network built in MATLAB software were employed to estimate the severity of damage.
Buckingham’s π theorem was used in the formulation of refined delamination factor (FDR).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: It was found that delamination is characterized by either delamination factor or adjusted delamination factor. In both of these formulations, effect of depth of damage (severity of damage) was not considered. Hence, the delamination factor is refined by including the terms that was much affected by the severity of damage. Refined delamination factor was calculated using the neural network built in MATLAB for various working conditions and validated using the standard test methods proposed in ASTM.
